abstract.text: Methods your app can implement to participate in SceneKit’s animation loop or perform additional rendering.

inlineContent.text: To build an app or game with SceneKit, you use an

protocol) to display your scene. Then, to add per-frame game logic, or to perform custom Metal or OpenGL rendering before or after SceneKit renders the scene, specify your own custom object that implements the
object (or other SceneKit renderer) runs a rendering loop that processes and then draws the scene.
shows the steps in this loop.
Each time through the rendering loop, a SceneKit view (or renderer) executes the following actions in order:
SceneKit executes actions and performs animations attached to the scene graph. (See the
SceneKit applies its physics simulation to any physics bodies in the scene. (See
SceneKit renders the scene graph in the view.

When building a game, you typically need to run logic relating to gameplay before each frame of animation. Game logic may include input handling, artificial intelligence, game scripting, or other tasks. Often, the results of this logic involve making changes to nodes or running actions on nodes.
provide places to implement your game logic. Which of these methods you implement for which tasks depends on your game design. For example, if your game uses physics, you might implement the
method to decide whether the player has won the game based on the state of physics bodies in the scene. If your gameplay isn’t based on the physics simulation, you might make such decisions in the
If you want to perform custom rendering before or after SceneKit renders the contents of the scene, implement one or both methods listed in

. These methods are appropriate for custom Metal or OpenGL drawing that does not depend on the structure or content of the scene graph. If you instead want to render a special effect that is attached to a specific location in the scene, see
. Or if you want to use GPU shader programs to customize SceneKit’s rendering of scene content, see

abstract.text: Create 3D games and add 3D content to apps using high-level scene descriptions, and easily add animations, physics simulation, particle effects, and realistic physically based rendering.
A simple, reusable animation that changes attributes of any node you attach it to.
The common interface for attaching animations to nodes, geometries, materials, and other SceneKit objects.
Information about the result of a scene-space or view-space search for scene elements.
A Core Animation layer that renders a SceneKit scene as its content.
Methods you can implement to use your own custom Metal or OpenGL drawing code to render content for a node.
The physics simulation attributes attached to a scene graph node.
The global simulation of collisions, gravity, joints, and other physics effects in a scene.
A renderer for displaying a SceneKit scene in an existing Metal workflow or OpenGL context.
Methods and properties common to the
, and
classes.
A delegate object that receives messages about SceneKit’s rendering process.
Methods your app can implement to participate in SceneKit’s animation loop or perform additional rendering.
Tells the delegate to perform any updates that need to occur after actions and animations are evaluated.
Tells the delegate that the renderer has rendered the scene.
Tells the delegate to perform any updates that need to occur after physics simulations are performed.
Tells the delegate to perform any updates that need to occur before actions, animations, and physics are evaluated.
Tells the delegate that the renderer has cleared the viewport and is about to render the scene.
Methods for customizing SceneKit’s rendering of geometry and materials using Metal or OpenGL shader programs.
A view for displaying 3D SceneKit content.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
